summary: This is an internal email from May 28, 2008, outlining the prosecution's concerns about further delays in the Jeffrey Epstein case. It details negative impacts including statute of limitations expirations for victims, weakening of the case as victims age, logistical issues with relocated victims, and potential undermining of a plea deal. It emphasizes the serious nature of the child exploitation crimes and the need for timely prosecution.

events.description: An internal communication is sent detailing the prosecution's arguments against further delays in the Epstein case, citing statute of limitations, victim welfare, and grand jury expiration.

events.title: Statute of Limitations Expiration
events.description: The statute of limitations is set to begin expiring in Fall 2008 for five of the 16 victims listed in the indictment, creating urgency for the prosecution.

keyFacts: The document reveals urgent prosecution concerns in May 2008 that delays would cause the state statute of limitations to expire for five of the 16 known victims by Fall 2008.
It states there are 'more than 20 known child victims' in the case, characterizing it as a child exploitation crime, not a non-violent white-collar crime.
The prosecution references a 'state resolution' or plea deal Epstein had signed months prior, which required him to plead to uncharged crimes, and further delay would let him escape its terms.
It notes victims have begun hiring private lawyers due to the delays, which Epstein's counsel could use to argue the victims are motivated by money.
The grand jury hearing the case was reportedly 'invested and wants to indict' but was set to expire soon, adding time pressure.
